hints.content: The parentheses tell us which two numbers to multiply first.

Imani solved the equation by multiplying $(\redE{2}\times\purpleE{3})$ first, and then multiplying by $\maroonE{7}$.

$\begin{align}
\redE{2} \times \purpleE{3} \times \maroonE{7} &=(\redE{2}\times\purpleE{3}) \times\maroonE{7}\\\\
&=\blueE{6}\times\maroonE{7}\\\\
&=42
\end{align}$

In the new equation below, we want to multiply $(\purpleE{3}\times\maroonE{7})$ first, and then multiply by $\redE{2}$.

$\begin{align}
\redE{2} \times \purpleE{3} \times \maroonE{7} &= \redE{2}\times(\purpleE{3}\times\maroonE{7})\\\\
&=\redE{2}\times\goldE{21}\\\\ 
&=42
\end{align}$

question.content:
Imani solved $\redE{2} \times \purpleE{3} \times\maroonE{7}$ using the equations below.

$\begin{align}
\redE{2} \times \purpleE{3} \times \maroonE{7} &=(\redE{2}\times\purpleE{3}) \times\maroonE{7}\\\\ 
&=6 \times\maroonE{7}\\\\\  
&=42
\end{align}$

**Use the equations below to solve $\redE{2} \times \purpleE{3} \times \maroonE{7}$ in a different way.**

||
-:|:-
$\redE{2} \times \purpleE{3} \times \maroonE{7}$ | $=\redE{2}\times(\purpleE{3} \times {}$ [[☃ numeric-input 1]] $)$  |
|$= \redE{2}\times {}$  [[☃ numeric-input 2]]|
|$= 42$|
